p.span: The DEPUTY SPEAKER ( Ms Claydon ) took the chair at 11:30, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (11:31): I present the 28th report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracey Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP
This committee is supported by staff of the Department of the House of Representatives

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament on 29 May and 26 June 2024.
1. The committee resolved to present the following 34 petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

p.span: From 1697 petitioners—requesting the reconsideration of recent changes to age limits for Temporary Graduate visas (subclass 485) (EN6181)
From 5 petitioners—requesting reduction of the residency requirements for Australian citizenship (EN6213)
From 125 petitioners—requesting that new age limits for Temporary Graduate visas (subclass 485) apply to students arriving after 1 July 2024 (EN6215)
From 5 petitioners—requesting the establishment of regulations to limit noise emissions (EN6216)
From 26 petitioners—requesting an investigation into COVID-19 vaccines (EN6217)
From 104 petitioners—requesting that a provider be deregistered from the National Disability Insurance Scheme (EN6218)
From 1620 petitioners—requesting that the Australian Government call for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza (EN6220)
From 25 petitioners—regarding the sale and serving of alcohol in Parliament House, and drug and alcohol testing (EN6221)
From 16 petitioners—regarding law enforcement tactics (EN6222)
From 2 petitioners—requesting a pathway to permanent residency for people who lived and worked in Australia during the COVID-19 pandemic (EN6223)
From 274 petitioners—requesting greater flexibility within the Support at Home program (EN6225)
From 109 petitioners—requesting an increase to the Age Pension Work Bonus threshold (EN6227)
From 28 petitioners—regarding concerns related to immigration numbers (EN6228)
From 69 petitioners—requesting legislation to strengthen whistleblower protections (EN6230)
From 73 petitioners—requesting the release of an individual whistleblower (EN6231)
From 14 petitioners—regarding concerns related to the removal of regional rail corridors (EN6233)
From 24 petitioners—requesting a smartphone application for e-petitions to the House of Representatives (EN6234)
From 9 petitioners—requesting the removal of English language assessments for Australian citizens applying to undertake tertiary education (EN6236)
From 8 petitioners—regarding the Australian Government's energy bill rebate scheme (EN6237)
From 8 petitioners—requesting additional funding for the Great Barrier Reef Aquarium Reef HQ in Townsville, Queensland (EN6238)
From 28 petitioners—regarding concerns relating to the Digital ID Bill 2024 (EN6240)
From 1557 petitioners—requesting that the live animal export industry be maintained (EN6241)
From 284 petitioners—requesting that Support at Home participants be given the ability to self-manage their age care services (EN6242)
From 13 petitioners—requesting the cancellation of a proposed 5G infrastructure project (EN6243)
From 24 petitioners—regarding concerns relating to a social media dance challenge (EN6244)
From 343 petitioners—requesting that a pardon be granted to Mr David McBride (EN6246)
From 13 petitioners—requesting that the House protect and promote secular democracy as a system of government (EN6247)
From 177 petitioners—requesting that eligibility for the Commonwealth Prac Payment scheme be widened to include medical students (EN6249)
From 99 petitioners—requesting the removal of the Capstone exam for prospective Registered Migration Agents (EN6250)
From 1922 petitioners—requesting that endometriosis be recognised as a condition resulting in permanent impairment by the National Disability Insurance Scheme (EN6251)
From 18 petitioners—requesting the option of advance payments for Centrelink support recipients (EN6253)
From 1342 petitioners—requesting the reintroduction of validation documents for authorised amateur radio operators (EN6254)
From 119 petitioners—requesting that temporary work visas be made available to international students who will be completing their studies in July 2024 (EN6255)
From 15 petitioners—requesting that the Australian Government provide incentives to the building industry (EN6256)

span.span: Ministerial responses received by the Committee on 26 June 2024

p.span: From the Treasurer to a petition requesting that foreign citizens be prohibited from owning any land or property in Australia (EN4359)
From the Treasurer to a petition requesting that the cost of diesel fuel be lowered (EN4807)
From the Treasurer to a petition requesting that changes be made to the superannuation guarantee rate to influence inflation (EN4822)
From the Treasurer to a petition regarding foreign ownership of Australian residential and agricultural land (EN5024)
From the Treasurer to a petition requesting that the Reserve Bank of Australia hold 2 percent of foreign currency reserves in Bitcoin (EN5167)
From the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to a petition requesting the establishment of a National War Widows Day (EN5634)
From the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government to a petition requesting upgrades to the rail network (EN5648)
From the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to a petition requesting the development of a code of conduct for veterans' advocates (EN5773)
From the Minister for Education to a petition regarding Higher Education Contribution Scheme repayments (EN5829)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition regarding restrictions on vaping products and e-cigarettes (EN5894)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition requesting the repeal of legislative changes affecting the regulation of e-cigarettes (EN5905)
From the Minister for Home Affairs to a petition regarding the Australian Victim of Terrorism Overseas Payment scheme (EN5922)
From the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme to a petition regarding the role of plan managers within the National Disability Insurance Scheme (EN5993)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition requesting that the drug belzutifan be included in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (EN6026)
From the Minister for Social Services to a petition regarding the Seniors Connected Village Hub program (EN6046)
From the Minister for Social Services to a petition requesting that the age of independence for Youth Allowance eligibility be lowered (EN6048)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition regarding the Russian presidential election in March 2024 (EN6065)

From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition regarding community pharmacies (PN0573)
PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (11:31): On behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions, I present the following 34 petitions:
International Students

A cohort of non-citizens completing their higher studies are eligible to apply SC-485 visa after achieving an award—Degree or Diploma Certificate. In the recent migration strategy released by the Department of Home Affairs, it is recommended that the SC-485 visa will have age eligibility reduced from 50 yrs to 35 yrs. This visa is quite significant for the international students who genuinely wish to gain exposure in the Australian work-force after finishing their education, so they return their home countries with complete knowledge and skills. People with plans to come to Australia for world class education and work experience are rethinking about their investments in the Australian higher education sector. Many of them are over 35 yrs of has and this decision negatively impacts the international students.

We therefore ask the House to maintain the current age limit for SC-485 visa or keep the age requirement aligned with permanent residency visas which is 45 yrs. The Department's argument in favour of this change is that they want to increase and maintain the productivity by giving SC-485 to younger international students. The proposed age limit of 35 yrs is too low since the applicants above this age bring expertise, exposure and skills to the country. There is a dilemma amongst the immigrants because for skilled and employer sponsored streams, the age limit is 45 yrs, and for temporary graduate visa SC-485 is 35 yrs. Therefore a vast number of students will be affected with this change.
from 1,697 citizens (Petition No. EN6181)
Citizenship

Australian citizenship is a privilege and a significant milestone for many migrants, symbolising their full integration into this great nation. The current citizenship by conferral application requires residency in Australia for at least 4 years, with the final year spent holding a Permanent Resident visa.

However, for those who came directly as Permanent Residents, 4 years is unreasonably long, considering they have already contributed significantly to the country and wish to be fully accepted into the community.
The current 4 years requirement can be a burden to many, for example numerous Permanent Residents would like to join the ADF but cannot meet the citizenship requirement.

As a Permanent Resident, one is already a permanent member of society, meaning that obtaining Australian citizenship is only a matter of time. Therefore, reducing this residence requirement would alleviate burdens for many.
We therefore ask the House to consider reducing the residence requirement from the current 4 years to 2 years, with at least 1 year spent holding a Permanent Resident visa.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN6213)
International Students
1. The proposed alterations to the age limit have a negative impact on students aged 35 and above who are in the process of completing their degrees after July 1, 2024.

2. Numerous individuals over the age of 35, who have left their jobs, secured educational loans, and relocated to Australia with their families, aimed at accessing better prospects for loan repayment and improved living standards. They've invested significant financial resources, time, and effort into pursuing education at Australian universities, banking on opportunities provided by the 485 visa pathway.
3. These modifications fail to uphold the government's commitment to offering post-degree employment opportunities.
4. It's unjust to revoke promised opportunities solely based on a student's age.

We therefore ask the House to make the changes in 485 visa rules applicable for students arriving after 1st of July 2024 which will resonate fairness, equality , ethics which are core values of the government .
from 125 citizens (Petition No. EN6215)
Heavy Vehicle Regulation

Community Noise created by Heavy Vehicles driving interstate when drivers are having their regulated breaks. The Noise created by the Trucks air conditioners and refrigerated Trailers has a Tonal noise that causes vibration and annoyance to local residents for the period that the Truck(s) are parked. Up to 4 Diesel Engines per unit are running in Truck Depots across Australia.

We therefore ask the House to Regulate the Noise Emissions by Vehicle Inspections other than ADR 83/00 to obtain a Decibel level below 35 when the Interstate Vehicles are parked in depots or rest areas. Buffer Zones as per GS 3 where it states a buffer zone of 200 metres should be mandatory from residential zones. SPP 5.4 should also be mandatory and along with Public Consultation before and during operation of the depots and rest areas.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN6216)
COVID-19: Vaccination

In 2021. I asked about exemption from vaccines I contacted politicians and health officials and. Tga. all said vaccines are tested and are vigorously tested well it turns out they are not . They recently removed AstraZeneca from sale because it causes blood clots .

We therefore ask the House to have an inquiry and investigate what the tga the politicians ( state premiers) and the priminister and health officials.of the day they new about vaccines they pushed people to get it publicly .we the people deserve the right to know. Also people were made to sign paperwork exempt the pharmaceuticals company's did they know. The risks were high .
from 26 citizens (Petition No. EN6217)
National Disability Insurance Scheme

Protection of Vulnerable Individuals: The actions of EVOLUTION SUPPORT SERVICES PTY LTD, Vincent Johnston, and Mark Hutton have endangered the well-being and rights of vulnerable individuals relying on NDIS services.
Upholding Ethical Standards: It is crucial to maintain the integrity and ethical standards within the disability support services sector by holding accountable those who engage in misconduct.
Ensuring Justice and Accountability: By taking swift and decisive action, we can ensure that justice is served, and those responsible for any wrongdoing are held accountable for their actions.
Safeguarding Public Trust: Upholding the reputation and trust in the NDIS system is essential to protect the interests of participants, families, and the broader community.
We therefore ask the House to Request for Removal of NDIS Accreditation and Business Licenses:

1. I request the swift removal of all NDIS accreditation and business licenses held by EVOLUTION SUPPORT SERVICES PTY LTD and any affiliated child or parent companies. The company has demonstrated unethical practices and misconduct that warrant such action.

2. Legal Action Against Owner, Vincent Johnston: It is imperative that legal action be taken against the owner, Vincent Johnston, for any violations of laws, regulations, or ethical standards. His actions have raised serious doubts about the integrity and credibility of the company.

3. Charges Against Mark Hutton for Crimes Against Protected Persons under NDIS: Mark Hutton, associated with EVOLUTION SUPPORT SERVICES PTY LTD, needs to be charged with crimes against Protected persons under the NDIS. This egregious behavior must be addressed with the utmost seriousness and appropriate legal consequences.
from 104 citizens (Petition No. EN6218)
Occupied Palestinian Territories

This petition is made to bring awareness to the situation that is currently happening in the Gaza strip and across all Palestinian land. We aim to bring awareness to the genocide that is currently happening in Palestine. We want a free Palestine, a free country without any illegal Israeli settlements and an IMMEDIATE CEASEFIRE NOW.

We therefore ask the House to call for an immediate ceasefire in the Gaza strip and for The Israeli military to COMPLETELY vacate the Gaza strip. We ask for all illegal Israeli settlers to leave the country of Palestine.
from 1,620 citizens (Petition No. EN6220)
Parliamentary Standards

Parliament house is a work place for thousands of people and should not be a place for those workers and Members of Parliament to get drunk. Businesses as large as Parliament house regularly run drug and alcohol testing of their employees all over Australia. The Department of Home Affairs has a publication which says:- The Department has a zero tolerance for the possession, use, or trafficking of prohibited drugs and is an alcohol-free workplace. Recently a member of the House has been shown collapsed and inebriated in the streets of Canberra after leaving Parliament House on the 7th of February 2024. The video of him was broadcast widely in mainstream media and social media. A previous petition asking MPs be drug and alcohol tested was refused by Senator McGrath as Minister assisting the Prime Minister, saying the issues raised in the petitions relate to the conduct of parliamentarians and are a matter for parliament to determine. Petitions are where we the voters can tell politicians what to do. Drug and alcohol testing of Parliament waste water has been stopped by the ACT government at the behest of Parliament.

We therefore ask the House to to work with the Senate to ban the sale and serving of alcohol in parliament house and to introduce drug and alcohol testing for all MPs and their staff while parliament is sitting.
from 25 citizens (Petition No. EN6221)
Law Enforcement

It is the role of law enforcement to try to reduce the instances of crime by enforcing the law and disrupting criminal conduct where possible. It should not be a function of law enforcement to induce or otherwise cause crimes to be committed,

Targeted operations regularly have the effect of causing offences to be committed that otherwise would not have occurred. On behalf of all the Australian citizens i feel that certain tactics that law enforcement use such as entrapment tactics or antagonistic tactics or tactics of the nature that can cause an induced increase of risk to commit a crime that would likely otherwise would not have been committed if these tactics were not used.

We therefore ask the House to ban law enforcement from participating in activities that induce or otherwise cause a criminal to commit an offence through entrapment tactics or other provocative and or antagonistic type tactics be made illegal due to the immoral and deceptive nature and behaviours that cause mistrust in the civilian community. Law enforcement are to uphold the law and keep the community safe. I believe public trust is negatively affected when law enforcement agencies use barbaric tactics such as entrapment type or antagonistic provocative type tactics. We ask the House to look into the negative affects of entrapment tactics have in creating a higher risk in a crime being committed and also causing mistrust from the Australian citizens how look up to law enforcement in a positive and respectful manner.
from 16 citizens (Petition No. EN6222)
Migration

The primary reason for this petition is to advocate for fairness and recognition for international students and employees who have chosen to remain in Australia during the Covid-19 pandemic. These individuals have faced numerous challenges and uncertainties, yet they have continued to contribute to the Australian economy and society without leaving the country.

We therefore ask the House to We, the undersigned, respectfully urge the Australian Government and Immigration Department to establish a special pathway for permanent residence or skilled visas for students and employees who remained in Australia during the Covid-19 pandemic. These individuals have steadfastly contributed to Australia's economy, culture, and society without leaving the country amidst unprecedented challenges.

Despite facing uncertainties and disruptions, these residents have continued to work, study, pay taxes, and support local businesses, thereby bolstering Australia's economy during the pandemic. Their resilience and commitment deserve recognition and a fair opportunity to secure permanent residency or skilled visas.

We propose a streamlined application process that considers their continuous contributions, including employment history, tax compliance, and community involvement. This pathway should acknowledge their loyalty and dedication to Australia during trying times, ensuring fairness for those who never left.

By implementing this special pathway, the Australian Government can demonstrate its commitment to fairness, inclusivity, and appreciation for the invaluable contributions of Covid-19 impacted residents. This initiative will not only provide security and stability to deserving individuals but also reinforce Australia's reputation as a welcoming and compassionate nation.
Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN6223)
Aged Care

We draw to the attention of the House the good intent of previous parliaments to support older Australians with essential in-home services. The Quality of Care Principles 2014 subclause 4(4) of Schedule 2, Meaning of services and supports for daily living; 'Services and supports for daily living include, but are not limited to, food services, domestic assistance, home maintenance, transport and recreational and social activities.' This meaning is not included in 2023 draft standards nor proposed Aged Care Act. In 2021 there were 3 references to 'specified exclusions'; following reforms the Aug 2023 Home Care Package manual has 23 references. Additional Clause: 9.3 Specified Exclusions. 'General home services that were never, or are generally not completed independently prior to age-related functional decline, including home repairs/maintenance/specialist cleaning performed by a tradesperson or other licensed professional'. Operational and policy inconsistencies exclude funding for an essential range of stay at home services such as unblocking drains, non-PBS medication and transport to visit family. Without policy change these exclusions will force older people without significant income to yield to fully subsidised residential care. Surely, this is contrary to the aims of Support at Home.

We therefore ask the House to urgently legislate that Support at Home embodies inclusions that will be flexible by nature to include such things as medically recommended non-PBS medicines, items of personal care and home maintenance that provide for the needs of older Australians to remain in their own homes in a safe and healthy environment.
from 274 citizens (Petition No. EN6225)
Pensions and Benefits
Increase the Work Bonus providing Aged Pensioners incentive to re-enter the workforce and ease the current skills shortage at no cost to Government, without disadvantaging those unable to work.
Why:
The current Work Bonus system discourages Pensioners to return to the workforce.
A Pensioner earnings gained from work over $150 p/week is reduced by 50%, this has not changed since July 2019.
Reduce a black cash economy.
Australian average wage 2009/10 to 2024 88% increase
Pension Sept 2009 to March 2024 66% increase
Work Bonus Sept 2009 to March 2024 20% increase
The $4,000 Work Bonus Cap increase had an actual one off value of $2,000, not enough to entice Aged Pensioners to change their lifestyle.
70,892 Aged Pensioners earned at least $250 in the last fortnight of March 2023. This number would increase to 99,691 if pre-covid levels were restored.

Increasing the threshold from $300 to $500 p/fortnight and restoring participation to pre-covid levels could realise a saving to Government of $2,880,000 or $70 Million including GST on additional spending.
AIM:

To immediately change the Work Bonus system providing Aged Pensioners incentive to re-enter the workforce and ease the current skills shortage at no cost to Government without disadvantaging those unable to work.
We therefore ask the House to
• Increase Work Bonus Threshold from $300 per fortnight to $500 per fortnight.
• Index Work Bonus Threshold in line with Aged Pension review every March and September.
• Consider combining Couples Work Bonus balance.
from 109 citizens (Petition No. EN6227)
Migration

The Shockingly, bewildering tidal wave of Immigration under the Albanese Government from countries such as India, China and many other Middle Eastern countries is causing the society that Australians and their forefathers built and fought in the World Wars to protect, to fall apart.
It is unsustainable, destructive and downright disrespectful of the citizens of Australia to continue to let this happen.

We don't have to go into the constant news that is broadcasted that is seemingly ignored by Labour for the parliament to know what we are talking about. The build up of crime, religious induced crime and many other negatives are going to keep building up, as it did in the UK, Germany and other such counties until this is stopped completely.
Your Australian people are not happy. Australians are becoming homeless, yet the borders are still open...Why??? Wake up Australia!
We therefore ask the House to close the borders completely until infrastructure is in place. Til Australians are in homes and not living by the side of the road in tents and can afford a proper meal.

Only medical staff and individuals that can actually benefit Australia and its citizens and improve the state of the country should be allowed in, and despite this, there should be strict rules in place to ensure that these individuals that come to our country want to integrate and do not just want to reap the benefits of our western country.
Australia and being a citizen of it is a privilege.
from 28 citizens (Petition No. EN6228)
Whistleblower Protection

Whistleblowers are an important part of democracy. Governments who oppose and punish whistleblowers are mostly dictators and authoritarian governments. We should not only stop punishing whistleblowers, we should encourage and support them.
This is especially true when the whistleblower is acting in conscience for the greater good and not acting out of personal benefit.
In circumstances when secret information and national security are involved, there should be a whistleblower commission or other body to facilitate this process without exposing national secrets.
We therefore ask the House to
1. Pass legislation specifically for the purpose of protecting whistleblowers and facilitating their efforts to expose wrong doing.
2. Set up a body to facilitate whistleblowers with the ability to expose wrong doing when secret information and state security are involved.
2. Pardon convicted whistleblowers with an official apology and financial compensation.
from 69 citizens (Petition No. EN6230)
Whistleblower Protection

This petition seeks the immediate release of a former military lawyer who acted in the public interest by disclosing classified information that revealed potential misconduct in overseas military operations.

A brave individual took a stand against what they believed to be unjust actions by leaking documents that brought critical issues to light. This act has sparked a national debate on the balance between operational secrecy and the public's right to know.
Reasons to Sign:
Protection for Whistleblowers:
The individual in question deserves protection under whistleblower laws, as the disclosure was made to inform the public and prevent further wrongdoing.
Public Interest:
The released information is crucial for public awareness and accountability in military conduct.
Legal and Ethical Implications:
The treatment of this case will set a precedent for future acts of whistleblowing and transparency in government operations.
Moral Duty:
Supporting those who risk their freedom to expose the truth is our collective responsibility.
We therefore ask the House to release this courageous man and to put REAL and tangible protections in place to protect whistleblowers in the future.

By signing this petition, you are not just supporting an individual, but also advocating for the principles of truth, justice, and transparency. Let's unite to send a strong message that integrity and ethical conduct should be upheld at all levels of government.
from 73 citizens (Petition No. EN6231)
Rail Infrastructure

Councils and states are being given unchecked powers allowing them to rip up regional railway lines that (could and should be brought back to service) in favor of a bike track, limiting the abilities to bring back rail connections to communities where it could be well utilized.

We therefore ask the House to enact legislation that bring back all rail corridors in regional areas back under crown land ownership and protects them from being truncated for bike paths. We also ask the house to push for a federally run and operated Freight and Passenger operated service to help ease the cost of living and reduce transport prices which are dictated by private freight operators, this includes the reinstatement of Passenger Services between Sydney and Perth, Perth and Darwin, Adelaide and Perth at an affordable rate. We also ask that ARTC be turned to a Non for Profit and existing infrastructure be brought to a higher level of quality (Grade 2 and above) to improve service times and reliability of Regional Rail Networks.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN6233)
Parliament

The House of Representatives' e-petition platform, currently only accessible through the APH website, is a crucial tool for democratic participation, enabling citizens to raise issues and express their views directly to the Parliament. However, its accessibility and user engagement can be significantly improved with the development of a dedicated mobile application for both Android and iOS devices. A mobile app would provide a more convenient and efficient way for Australians to access, engage with, and monitor e-petitions. Given the widespread use of smartphones, an app would enhance civic engagement by allowing users to receive real-time notifications about new petitions, updates on petitions they have signed, and alerts based on specific keywords of interest. This modernisation is essential to ensure that more Australians can participate actively in their democracy, stay informed about issues they care about, and have their voices heard in the decision-making process.

We therefore ask the House to develop and launch a dedicated mobile application for both Android and iOS platforms to enhance the accessibility and functionality of the e-petition system. This app should include features such as:
1. Intuitive browsing, signing, and sharing.
2. Petition progress tracking.
3. Real-time notifications for updates.
4. Enhanced search and filtering.
5. Dark Mode for low-light conditions.
6. Open-source code for transparency.
7. Multi-language support.
8. Accessibility features for all users.
By implementing these features, the app will not only make the e-petition process more accessible and engaging but also foster greater public participation and transparency in our democratic process.
from 24 citizens (Petition No. EN6234)
Universities

I applied to Study in Multiple Australian universities to Study . Because I was born Overseas this makes it bit difficult because they want me to do an english exam . I have no issue whatsoever however i believe it is a waste of time and resources and very discriminatory policy .

I am an Australian Citizen and been living in Australia for nearly two decades . I find this bizzare. When i came to Australia I had to do that also when i applied for my permanent Residency i had to do that english exam which is fair enough . However after becoming a citizen why cannot we be treated as other Australians who are born here .That is very Discriminatory .

We therefore ask the House to remove this requirement for Australian citizens so there are no such barriers for them and they can continue to pursue their studying and dreams and contribute to the society .
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN6236)
Economy: Energy Prices
Some people do not want, need or feel comfortable about receiving the newly-announced $300 electricity rebate.

This is especially true now that this money is not truly present in the public purse that is in a trillion dollar debt, meaning that this electricity subsidy will eventually have to be paid by future generations—and there are people who feel it improper to impose the costs of their lifestyle on innocent and yet unborn future generations.

We therefore ask the House to allow electricity customers to opt out and forego the electricity rebate by instructing their energy provider not to accept this $300 on their behalf, nor deduct it from their electricity bills.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN6237)
Great Barrier Reef Aquarium
The federal government committed $80 million to refurbish Great Barrier Reef Aquarium "Reef HQ" in Townsville.
A change in federal government led to a change in scope and decision by the federal government to demolish and rebuild a new, state of the art, Great Barrier Reef aquarium.
In 2021 Reef HQ was demolished with people, community and stakeholders involved in Great Barrier Reef education told repeatedly the aquarium would be reopen for business by 2026.

The future of the Great Barrier Reef aquarium is now in tatters with a federal government failing to commit funding for the redevelopment of Reef HQ. An entire generation of primary school children are missing out on first hand education involving the Great Barrier Reef.

There are some things where politics needs to set politics aside and this is one of them. Education and research involving the Great Barrier Reef is entwined with the very fabric of Australia and is a national responsibility.

Let us together stand for Great Barrier Reef Education. Townsville is currently left with a vacant site where the greatly prided Reef HQ aquarium stood until 2021. The Townsville community, North Queensland residents and Australia need, as a matter of urgency, certainty over the future of the Great Barrier Reef Aquarium, education and research facility.

We therefore ask the House to immediately commit funding to resume the redevelopment of Reef HQ. Vital infrastructure providing for education and research about the Great Barrier Reef and an international tourism destination.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN6238)
Australian Society

The Digital Bill proposes troubling measures that could infringe upon our privacy and freedom online. By granting excessive power to authorities to monitor and regulate digital activities, it threatens the very essence of internet freedom. Such legislation could stifle innovation, deter entrepreneurship, and undermine trust in digital platforms. Moreover, the vague language and broad scope of the bill raise concerns about potential abuse and discrimination against marginalized communities. Instead of fostering a safe and open digital environment, it risks creating a climate of fear and censorship. We must advocate for legislation that strikes a balance between safeguarding individual rights and ensuring digital security, without sacrificing one for the other.

We therefore ask the House to of representatives Addressing the esteemed members of the House of Representatives in the Australian Parliament, I urge you to prioritize the pressing issues that affect our nation's future. It is paramount that we focus on policies that promote sustainability, equity, and progress for all Australians. From addressing climate change to fostering economic resilience and social cohesion, our actions today shape the trajectory of tomorrow. Let us work together across party lines to enact legislation that reflects the will and aspirations of the people we serve. Together, we can build a stronger, fairer, and more prosperous Australia for generations to come
from 28 citizens (Petition No. EN6240)
Live Animal Exports

We call upon the Federal Government to take immediate action to protect the livelihoods of Australian producers. Despite the industry's ongoing efforts to meet and exceed welfare standards, the Government's agenda appears to sabotage these efforts, playing on the misconceptions held by the public. This is not about animal welfare; it is a deliberate attack on Australian producers by the bureaucrats elected to safeguard our interests.

Our industry has achieved the highest possible welfare standards. The data clearly indicates that death rates are higher in domestic paddocks than they are at sea. This fact alone demonstrates that our current practices are among the best in the world.

The Government's approach is destabilising an essential sector of our economy. The belief that achieving excellent outcomes would secure governmental support has proven to be a fallacy. It is now evident that we have been misguided in thinking that compliance and improvement would shield us from detrimental policies.

The Government is currently withholding a report it commissioned to understand the implications of banning live export. This lack of transparency is unacceptable. We demand the immediate release of this report to the public.
Together, let us safeguard the future of Australian agriculture and ensure the prosperity of our farmers and producers.
We therefore ask the House to Halt any further actions that undermine the live export industry.
Ensure transparent and accountable governance that truly protects the best interests of Australian producers.
Recognise and support the critical role of free markets in the economic stability and sustainability of rural communities.
from 1,557 citizens (Petition No. EN6241)
Aged Care

Older Australians receiving in home support draw to the attention of the House unintended outcomes from Aged Care standards and regulation. In preparation for a new Aged Care Act, the department of Health and Aged Care has proposed the Strengthening of Aged Care Quality and Safety Standards and a strategic early introduction of methodologies to prepare supplier and workers for the proposed Support at Home program. A consequence of these changes is that service providers are being asked to provide greater governance over the ways in which services are provided. This extra governance assumes that all older people receiving funding are incapable of making independent decisions about their lives with the result that individual choice over the self-management of home care packages is severely constrained. On-line service providers are insisting that care plans, which include private and personal details, must be shared with all workers providing aged care services; regardless of worker expertise and lack of qualifications they are asked to report on welfare concerns and living conditions of people receiving aged care services. Though these conditions may be well intended they are a violation of privacy and dignity of risk.

We therefore ask the House to urgently legislate that older people receiving age care services have the right to self-manage their age care services which includes the right to directly engage aged care workers of their choice and that reports by workers are restricted to the services provided.
from 284 citizens (Petition No. EN6242)
Telecommunications
Cell phone towers (Base Stations) emit Radio frequency (RF) Electromagnetic energy (EME). Known as non-iodising radiation.
The World Health Organisation (WHO) classified radio frequency radiation as a possible 2B carcinogen. (Cancer causing)

The cell phone tower is located in the middle of a residential area. This area has sensitive locations only metres away. *Sensitive locations are those close to children (highly affected by radiation)*. It is only a few metres from a major playground, two daycare centres and a highly populated indigenous area. Radiation exposure to the community is going to quadruple which will have many health risks to our community. WE SAY NO!!!!!

The Electromagnetic energy (EME) around the base station at Fort Largs Police Academy 5017 was tested. The levels calculated by Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency (ARPANSA). They are available in detail on the (ARPANSA) website. Below are the CLEAR DIFFERENCE IN RESULTS WHEN 5G IS INSTALLED.
The maximum EME level calculated for the existing systems at the site is 1.11% (3G & 4G)
The maximum EME level calculated for the proposed changes at the site is 4.20% (3G, 4G & 5G)
There is no safe amount of radiation. Listed are some; of many, health effects taken from WHO, caused by this type of RF EME exposure:
1) Lowered fertility
2) Neurological/neuropsychiatric effects
3) Effects on cellular DNA.
5) Oxidative stress/free radical damage
7) Cancer including tumour progression, tissue invasion and metastasis.
We therefore ask the House to cancel the proposed 5G networks being proposed at the site 5017003.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN6243)
Child Safety

Concerned about the impact of the Skibidi dance craze on young children? Join us in promoting a safer and more age-appropriate environment by advocating for a ban on Skibidi for kids under 10. Let's protect our little ones and ensure they engage in activities that are suitable for their age group. Together, we can create a more responsible and kid-friendly entertainment culture!
We therefore ask the House to please ban the word skibidi it is harming our young bloods
from 24 citizens (Petition No. EN6244)
McBride, Mr David William
Request a full unconditional Pardon for David McBride war veteran of Afghanistan who exposed Australia's war crimes cover up by Defence Bureaucrats

We therefore ask the House to request the Governor General Head of State for the Commonwealth of Australia to give a pardon for David McBride Whistleblower war veteran of Afghanistan who exposed Australia's war crimes to the public by the media and the failure of the Federal government bureaucracy to uphold the laws passed by parliament under commonwealth constitution s51 external affairs powers Treaty obligations.
These laws were incorporating into Australian domestic Law ie war crimes
Crimes against humanity genocide under
GENEVA CONVENTIONS ACT 1957
Torture Act 1988
COMMONWEALTH CRIMINAL CODE D268 ROME STATUTES
from 343 citizens (Petition No. EN6246)
Australian Society

The world is becoming a dangerous place, with dictatorships and theocracies incrementally pushing the line in a direction to gain more control and influence in the world and impose their values and power on everyone else. This is especially true in our own region.
Australia can incrementally push back against this trend . We should take the first step now.
We therefore ask the House to
1. Pass a law which states that "Australia adopts the principle that the only legitimate form of government is a secular democracy".
2. Encourage like minded governments to do the same.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN6247)
Tertiary Education: Mandatory Work Placement

Medical students complete over 2000 hours of mandatory unpaid clinical placements, the most out of all respective healthcare fields. This does not consider the additional thousands of study hours, coursework, and travel students undertake.

For those who come from disadvantaged backgrounds, have families, or who are self-supporting, the cost of completing over 2000 hours of mandatory unpaid clinical placement and ongoing course requirements is crippling. Managing employment and families on top of this means many medical students are forced to make impossible decisions, with some leaving the degree before finishing.

In 2024, the Australian Universities Accord recommended financial support for nursing, care, and teaching professions in mandatory placements to reduce financial hardship. Medical students were not included.

In response to this, a Commonwealth Prac Payment was established to support students undertaking placements in these important professions. This ensures that students studying to fill some of the most needed roles in healthcare and society receive the support they need to finish their degrees.

Medical students and doctors also do important jobs and need support, especially those from disadvantaged backgrounds. Without this critical support, studying to be a doctor will only be for the students who can afford it. This threatens the diversity of our future healthcare system, locking out potential doctors with essential and unique skill sets that our healthcare system desperately needs.

We therefore ask the House to include medical students in the Commonwealth Prac Payment scheme and to include medical students in the Accord Report considerations for financial support for placements.
from 177 citizens (Petition No. EN6249)
Tertiary Education: Migration Law

A prospective registered migration lawyer needs to undergo a capstone assessment administered by Legal Training Australia, which is perceived as unfair and designed to put mental pressure on prospective RMAs. Currently, to become a registered migration agent, an individual completes a graduate diploma in Australian migration law and practice, offered by several renowned Australian universities. The tuition fee is around $25,000. Universities conduct various exams, including written and oral tests, covering the entire Migration Act 1958 and Migration Regulation 1994. They also assess students through exams and assignments based on critical case studies, client scenarios, visa application processes, and appeal procedures at the AAT.

The design of the capstone exam is redundant, as it duplicates the comprehensive assessments already conducted by the universities. Thus, the necessity of this additional exam is questionable. Does it imply that the universities failed to adequately assess the students? Additionally, LTA charges approximately $2,300 for this exam, which is quite expensive. Many prospective RMAs need to attempt this exam multiple times to pass, resulting in additional financial burdens. Since universities have already enrolled, assessed, and passed these students, the capstone exam seems like a futile exercise, wasting the time and money of prospective RMAs.

We therefore ask the House to reconsider this current law and abolish the capstone exam for compelling and compassionate reasons. Prospective RMAs and their families may be suffering from financial crises due to the post-pandemic economic downturn, and they eagerly need to work in their dream profession to support their families.
from 99 citizens (Petition No. EN6250)
National Disability Insurance Scheme

The NDIS does not recognise Endometriosis as a disability or under any listed condition eligible for support. The NDIS denies the eligibility for access to many supports which are beneficial to those who are living with this condition. Treatments such as physio, osteopathy, naturopathy are expensive and due to the frequency of the need for long term management while waiting for surgical options this is financially detrimental and often we are forced to go without these treatments, endometriosis qualifies under criteria for supports available already under NDIS & also should recognise and support the impact of that it has on parents and the effect it can have on their abilities to support themselves and their children effecting the physical, mental & emotional wellbeing of parents which impacts on quality care for children. The WHO response to endometriosis- Endometriosis has significant social, public health and economic implications. It can decrease quality of life due to severe pain, fatigue, depression, anxiety and infertility. Some individuals with endometriosis experience debilitating pain that prevents them from going to work or school. Addressing endometriosis will empower those affected by it by supporting their human right to the highest standard of sexual and reproductive health, quality of life and overall well-being.

We therefore ask the House to enforce the NDIS recognise endometriosis as a PERMENANT Disability and is eligible under the List D Conditions resulting in multiple types of impairment for access to support under the NDIS & support with accessing treatments which can not bulkbilled
from 1,922 citizens (Petition No. EN6251)
Pensions and Benefits

Certain citizens of Australia are concerned with the fact that when they are on weekly Centrelink payments, they become ineligible for advance payments—despite the fact that the payment they receive has NOT changed. It is still the same amount, paid in weekly instalments (which is SIGNIFICANTLY easier to manage and let's be honest, should be the default).

It should also be noted that people on welfare needing advances (which aren't even free, they have to be paid back) is a sign of a MASSIVE failing of the welfare system, given we can't afford to survive on what we are given.
We therefore ask the House to allow ALL Centrelink recipients receiving eligible payments to receive an advance if required, regardless of weekly or fortnightly payments.
from 18 citizens (Petition No. EN6253)
Amateur Radio Licences

The International Telecommunications Union defines amateur radio as "a radiocommunication service for the purpose of self-training, intercommunication and technical investigations carried out by amateurs, that is, by duly authorised persons interested in radio technique solely with a personal aim and without pecuniary interest."
Australia has approximately 15,000 authorised amateur radio operators and their authorisation comes from the Australian Communications & Media Authority (ACMA).

In February 2024 the ACMA introduced a class licence in place of the previous apparatus licence. The previous apparatus licence provided individuals with a licence document which could be shown to authorities and services domestically and internationally to demonstrate that the holder was a duly authorised person. There are numerous situations where such a document is required.

The class licence does not provide for such a document, leaving operators unable to demonstrate that they are duly authorised. ACMA provided a two-page letter prior to the introduction of the class licence, however, that letter has been shown to be inadequate in both content and appearance for validation purposes. The letter does not adequately confirm that a valid licence or call sign is currently held.

An appropriate "call sign certificate" document exists, but it is only issued by ACMA to new assignments. ACMA declines to issue a call sign certificate retrospectively as a suitable replacement for the now withdrawn apparatus licence.
We therefore ask the House to direct the ACMA to restore the practice of issuing to authorised Australian amateur radio operators an appropriate and acceptable validation document.
from 1,342 citizens (Petition No. EN6254)
International Students

Please help students get 5 years of work visa because Universities will finish their procedures for 2024 by July 1st week and which is why all students finishing their studies will receive 3 years of work visa which is not fair.

We therefore ask the House to please grant 5 years of work visa for students finishing their studies by July 2024 just because of 4-5 days we all will loose 2 years which are very important for every student.
from 119 citizens (Petition No. EN6255)
Building Industry

Australia has a rich multicultural society, which is a cornerstone of our national identity and strength. Our diversity enriches our communities, fosters innovation, and enhances our global perspective. However, we face a significant housing shortage that threatens the well-being of both existing residents and new arrivals who seek to contribute to and become part of our vibrant society.

To maintain and nurture our multicultural heritage, it is imperative that we ensure all new Australians have access to adequate accommodation and a high quality of life. Therefore, we urgently call on the government to provide substantial incentives and support to the building industry. These measures should include:
- Tax Incentives and Grants: Implementing tax breaks and financial grants for construction companies that prioritise affordable housing projects.
- Streamlined Approval Processes: Reducing bureaucratic red tape to expedite the approval and development of new housing projects.

- Investment in Training and Employment: Investing in training programs to equip workers with the necessary skills to meet the demands of a growing building industry, thus creating jobs and stimulating economic growth.
- Sustainable and Inclusive Development: Ensuring that new housing projects are sustainable, inclusive, and designed to accommodate the diverse needs of all Australians.
By taking these steps, we can support our building industry, address the housing shortage, and uphold our commitment to being a welcoming, inclusive nation.
We therefore ask the House to establish building industry support incentives
from 15 citizens (Petition No. EN6256)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (11:31): I present 19 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented.
Foreign Investment
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4359 on drafting a bill for debate to pass a national law that no non-Australian citizen can own any percentage of rural agricultural land, residential, industrial or commercial property within Australia.

Foreign investment plays an important and beneficial role in the Australian economy. It helps drive economic growth, creates skilled jobs, improves access to overseas markets and enhances productivity. Foreign investment has helped build Australia's economy and it will continue to enhance the wellbeing of Australians by supporting economic growth and innovation.

The Government recognises there are community concerns around foreign ownership of Australian properties impacting Australian's ability to access affordable housing. With very limited exceptions, foreign persons require foreign investment approval before acquiring an interest in residential land and are prohibited from purchasing established housing.

In light of this, the Government has recently announced higher fees for the purchase of established homes, increased penalties for those that leave properties vacant, strengthened compliance activity, and lowering application fees for foreign investment in Build to Rent projects to support the delivery of more homes across Australia.
The changes announced include:
a tripling of foreign investment fees for the purchase of established homes;
a doubling of vacancy fees for all foreign-owned dwellings purchased since 9 May 2017 (which together mean a six-fold increase in vacancy fees for future purchases of established dwellings);
enhancing the ATO's compliance regime to ensure foreign investors comply with the rules, including selling their residence when required.
These measures strengthen Australia's already robust foreign investment framework to help ensure foreign investment in residential property is in our national interest.

With regards to agricultural land, as a component of the national interest test, the foreign investment framework typically requires there to have been an equal opportunity for Australians to invest in any agricultural land or entities before approval can be granted. Generally, approval will not be granted for an acquisition of such an interest where the land or entity was not offered for sale through an open and transparent sale process.

If it is ultimately determined that a proposal would be contrary to the national interest or to national security it will not be approved, or conditions will be imposed to mitigate risks to our national interest.

Further, to help ensure transparency of foreign investment into Australian land, the Government has also overseen the creation of the Register of Foreign Ownership of Australian Assets which began operation on 1 July 2023. Foreign investors are required to report to The Register when they acquire or sell land interests. The Register will increase visibility of foreign investments made in Australia.
Should the petitioner require further information on Australia's foreign investment policy and framework please refer to foreigninvestment.gov.au.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Diesel
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4807 on House to seriously discuss and lower the cost of diesel. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) monitors and reports on prices, costs and profits relating to the supply of petroleum products in Australia. As part of this task, the ACCC monitors retail prices of unleaded petrol, diesel and liquefied petroleum gas in all Australian capital cities and more than 190 regional locations. The ACCC reports on diesel and petrol prices in its quarterly petrol monitoring reports. The ACCC does not set petrol or diesel prices in Australia. Prices are set by the market.

As the independent regulator, the ACCC investigates concerns about anti-competitive conduct and misleading representations in fuel markets and takes appropriate action. The ACCC also engages with major retailers and wholesalers to ensure that they do not mislead Australian consumers about the rationale for any price rises.

The level of competition between fuel retailers plays an important role in the price of fuel. To help drive competition, the ACCC recommends that consumers take advantage of fuel price websites and mobile applications that allow them to select the best time to purchase fuel, as well as the cheapest location.

I also note your points about the environmental impacts of diesel fuel. While diesel engines generally use less fuel and produce less carbon dioxide than equivalent petrol engines, diesel engines also produce higher levels of noxious emissions (such as oxides of nitrogen and particulates). These emissions can also impact on the environment by causing smog and impacting on the quality of the air we breathe.

For these reasons, regulators in Australia and overseas have implemented strict standards that limit noxious emissions from vehicle exhausts. These standards have been progressively tightened for both petrol and diesel vehicles under successive governments over the past 50 years in line with improvements in technology.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Superannuation
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4822 on introducing compulsory savings from pre-tax salaries and wages to reduce inflation.

The Government is committed to assisting all members of the community to achieve a dignified retirement. The superannuation guarantee, and its legislated increase to 12 per cent, is a central part of the Government's retirement income policy to bolster Australians' superannuation savings, helping retirees achieve a higher standard of living in retirement than with the Age Pension alone. Changing the superannuation guarantee rate over time to influence aggregate demand and inflation is not aligned with this objective.

The recent Review of the Reserve Bank found that the operational framework used by the Reserve Bank to pursue its monetary policy objectives is broadly fit for purpose. The Review did not recommend a change to the Reserve Bank's use of interest rates as the primary tool of monetary policy.

The Government understands that households are under pressure from high inflation and higher interest rates. The Government doesn't second guess the decisions taken by the independent Reserve Bank, which aims to keep inflation between 2 and 3 per cent a year. But we do agree with the Reserve Bank that inflation remains the number one challenge in our economy, and that's why it is our number one priority. That is why the Government is delivering responsible cost of living relief in a way that doesn't add to inflation.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Foreign Investment
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5024 on foreign acquisitions of Australian land, including residential and agricultural land.
Petition EN5024 raises concerns regarding the impact of foreign investment in Australian land, and affordability for Australians wishing to purchase land.

Foreign investment plays an important and beneficial role in the Australian economy. It helps drive economic growth, creates skilled jobs, improves access to overseas markets and enhances productivity. Foreign investment in housing and agriculture is important in delivering on Australia's national priority areas including boosting Australia's construction capabilities, and contributing to the prosperity of local businesses, rural communities and the Australian economy.

The Government recognises community concerns around foreign ownership of certain Australian assets, including residential real estate and agricultural land. That is why the foreign investment framework allows the Government to take these concerns into consideration by reviewing foreign investment proposals on a case-by-case basis to ensure they are not contrary to the national interest or national security. If it is determined that a proposal is contrary to the national interest, it will not be approved or conditions will be applied to safeguard the national interest.
Residential real estate

In relation to residential real estate, the Government's policy is to channel foreign investment into new residential dwellings, as opposed to established dwellings, as this creates additional jobs in the construction industry and bolsters Australia's housing stock. With very limited exceptions, foreign persons generally require foreign investment approval before acquiring an interest in residential land and are also prohibited from purchasing established housing. Foreign persons are required to pay a fee for each investment application. In addition to fees for residential land applications, a vacancy fee will generally be payable if the residential property is left vacant for at least six months in a year.

In recognition of the need to balance pressures on the housing market, the Government has recently announced higher fees for the purchase of established homes, increased penalties for those that leave properties vacant, strengthened compliance activity, and lowered application fees for foreign investment in Build to Rent projects to support the delivery of more homes across Australia.
The changes announced include:
a tripling of foreign investment fees for the purchase of established homes;
a doubling of vacancy fees for all foreign-owned dwellings purchased since 9 May 2017 (which together mean a six-fold increase in vacancy fees for future purchases of established dwellings); and
enhancing the Australian Taxation Office's compliance regime to ensure foreign investors comply with the rules, including selling their residence when required.

These measures strengthen Australia's already robust foreign investment framework to help ensure foreign investment in residential property is in our national interest. The revenue generated will support the Government's ambitious housing agenda to boost the supply of all housing, including social housing, affordable housing, more homes to rent and more homes to buy, to address the cost and supply of housing for buyer or renters.
Agricultural land

In relation to agricultural land, foreign persons generally require foreign investment approval before acquiring an interest in agricultural land where the cumulative value of their agricultural land holdings exceeds (or would exceed with the proposed investment) $15 million. If it is ultimately determined that a proposal would be contrary to the national interest or to national security it will not be approved, or conditions will be applied to safeguard the national interest.

As a component of the national interest test, the foreign investment framework typically requires there to have been an equal opportunity for Australians to invest in any agricultural land or entities before approval can be granted. Generally, approval will not be granted for an acquisition of such an interest where the land or entity was not offered for sale through an open and transparent sale process. This requirement ensures Australian bidders have an equal opportunity to participate in a given sale process.

Further, to help ensure transparency of foreign investment in Australian land, the Government has also overseen the creation of the Register of Foreign Ownership of Australian Assets which began operation on 1 July 2023. Foreign investors are required to report to the Register when they acquire or sell land interests. The Register will increase visibility of foreign investments made in Australia.
Should the petitioner require further information on Australia's foreign investment policy and framework, please refer to foreigninvestment.gov.au.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Reserve Bank of Australia
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5167 about mandating the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) to hold 2 per cent of foreign currency reserves in bitcoin.

The Reserve Bank Act 1959 provides the RBA with powers to deal in foreign exchange to achieve its policy objectives, including through the implementation of monetary policy and providing foreign exchange services to its customers, principally the Government.

The independent RBA takes its own decisions about the composition of its foreign currency reserve assets to achieve its policy objectives. The Government is committed to the operational independence of the RBA and does not intervene in these decisions.
The mandate under which the RBA manages reserves requires investments in assets of high credit quality and sufficient liquidity to allow the Bank to meet its policy objectives.
Further information about the RBA's management of foreign currency reserves can be found at: https://www.rba.gov.au/mkt-operations/intl-mkt-oper.html.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
War Widows Day
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 20 February 2024 on behalf of War Widows Australia NSW regarding a petition calling for a national War Widows Day.
I do acknowledge New South Wales, the Australian Capital Territory, Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia in formally recognising 19 October as War Widows Day.
There are currently five officially gazetted (proclaimed) annual national days of observance for significant military commemorations in Australia:

The two principal national days of commemoration are Anzac Day and Remembrance Day. Anzac Day (25 April), which is enshrined in the Anzac Day Act 1995, honours Australian men and women who have served in the defence forces in all wars, conflicts and peace operations. Remembrance Day (11 November) was proclaimed by the Governor-General in 1997, and is when Australia pays tribute to those who have died or suffered during wars and conflicts.
The other three days are Bombing of Darwin Day (19 February), Merchant Navy Day (3 September) and Battle for Australia Day (the first Wednesday in September).

While there are currently no plans to increase the number of officially proclaimed annual national days of observance for significant military commemorations in Australia, I do support increased recognition for veteran families and the unique challenges they face, both now and in the past. Legislated recognition is not a prerequisite for commemorating wartime history and honouring our veterans and their families. Proclaiming a date that commemorates a specific veteran group is also not inclusive of the vast array of other service experiences of veterans or families who did not participate in that group.

It is important to note that many other days of commemoration, such as Vietnam Veterans Day on 18 August, have come into being by general acceptance from the veteran and wider communities but are not proclaimed. The Australian Government currently acknowledges these days through media releases, community engagement activities and other types of recognition. It supports and encourages veterans, their families and the community to hold commemorative services. However, the Government does not select the date, leaving that to ex-service organisations and veteran communities. In this regard I note the recent acknowledgements of War Widows Day in some States and Territories.
Thank you for bringing the petition calling for a National War Widows Day to the Australian Government's attention.
Yours faithfully,
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Keogh(Petition No. EN5634)
Rail Infrastructure
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 12 February 2024 regarding petition 'EN5648—Transform Rail for Faster Travel, Greener Future, and Stronger Economy' which was presented in the House of Representatives on 12 February 2024. I apologise for the delay in responding.
The Sydney to Melbourne rail line is part of the Australian Rail Track Corporation's (ARTC) North-South Rail Corridor that links Melbourne to Acacia Ridge in Queensland via Sydney.

While the Australian Government operates and maintains the North-South Rail Corridor for freight rail between Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane through the ARTC, passenger rail services are the responsibility of state and territ01y governments. The petitioners may also wish to write to the relevant Minister in the New South Wales and Victorian Governments in relation to this matter:
NSW—the Hon Jo Haylen MP, Minister for Transport
VIC—the Hon Danny Pearson MP, Minister for Transport Infrastructure

The Government recognises the importance of Australia's rail network and is committed to investing in the right infrastructure projects that support our growing cities and regions to ensure a productive and efficient rail network. The ARTC plans improvement works on the interstate and north-south networks.

In late 2020, the ARTC completed a $235 million upgrade to the North East Rail Line between Melbourne and Albany. The upgrade delivered a track that meets the Victorian Class 2 track performance standards and has enabled the Victorian Government's passenger rail operator, V/Line, to introduce new, faster and more reliable 'VLocity' trains. Works included track tamping, mud-hole removal, ballast improvements, level crossing renewals, upgrading timber bridges and the installation of new rail cross-overs.

Through the 2024-25 Federal Budget, the Government will invest $540 million in support of the Australian Rail Track Corporation's (ARTC) Network Investment Program (NIP) which aims to improve the resilience, reliability and productivity of the Interstate Rail Freight Network managed by ARTC.

This includes $150 million to fund track rehabilitation and ride quality projects on up to 315km of track between Albany to Sydney, with a focus on undercutting, replacement of ballast, removal of mud holes to improve corridor reliability, increase in ride quality and remove Temporary Speed Restrictions. Some aspects of this line are up to 143 years old, having been constructed in 1881.

In 2021, the Government committed $41.6 million to the Southern Highlands Overtaking Opportunities project which will improve flexibility, efficiency and reliability of freight and passenger services by allowing 1,800 metre freight trains to be ove1taken by faster services. It will also improve the effectiveness of rail freight between Sydney and Melbourne by reducing the freight transit time by up to 39 minutes across a 12-hour rail journey.

The Government has set ambitious carbon reduction targets for which strong action will be required, and the Government recognises the important role rail will need to play. As part of this work, opportunities to pursue decarbonisation through the increased adoption of low emissions transportation methods, such as rail, are being explored. You can find out more about the work of my depa1tment to support this commitment through the Transport and Infrastructure Net Zero Roadmap and Action Plan at www.infrastructure.gov.au/infrastrncture-transport-vehicles/transport-and-infrastructure-net- zero-roadmap-and-action-plan.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Ms Catherine King
Veterans
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 26 February 2024 regarding Petition EN5773, requesting the House of Representatives to initiate such processes to develop and legislate a veterans' advocate code of conduct.

Veterans' advocacy is not a regulated activity and is predominantly undertaken by ex-service organisations (ESOs). However, services can also be provided by other parties e.g. solicitors or private advocates.

ESO advocates are eligible to receive training through the Advocacy Training and Development Program (ATDP), which offers nationally accredited training in military advocacy and support. Advocates who undertake ATDP training are provided with a code of ethics that outlines the principles, values and behaviours expected of advocates trained under the ATOP. They are also eligible to be covered by professional indemnity insurance facilitated through the Veterans' Indemnity and Training Association—VITA. Further information on the ATOP and VITA can be found at web.atdp.org.au

Currently there are over 600 individual advocates who are qualified through ATOP and are registered with an ESO. Details of the ESOs, which provide these services, can be found by the veteran community on the Advocacy Register at advocateregister.org.au.

The Department of Veterans' Affairs is also working with the veteran community to explore the establishment of an independent veterans' advocacy governance body to further support and promote a credible, reliable, and professional network of advocates. It is anticipated that this body will be responsible for setting and overseeing the ethical and service delivery standards for veteran advocacy. Ensuring Australian veterans and their families are able to access the range of entitlements and support available to them is a high priority for the Australian Government.
Thank you for providing me with Petition EN5773, I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours faithfully,
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Keogh
Universities
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 26 February 2024 regarding Petition EN5829, in relation to Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) indexation and repayments.

The Australian Government will wipe around $3 billion in student debt for more than 3 million Australians—easing pressure on workers and students across the country. It will provide significant relief for students while continuing to protect the integrity and value of the Higher Education Loan Program (HELP) and other student loan systems, which have massively expanded tertiary access for more Australians.

As part of the 2024-25 Budget, the Government is delivering on reforms recommended by the Australian Universities Accord. The Government will cap the HELP indexation rate to the lower of either the Consumer Price Index (CPI) or the Wage Price Index. The change will be applied retrospectively from 1 June 2023.

Individuals will receive a credit to their outstanding student loan debt balance for any difference between the indexation rate under current legislation and the new indexation rate once the relevant legislation has been amended. This will apply to all HELP, VET Student Loan and Australian Apprenticeship Support Loan and other student loan accounts that existed on 1 June last year.
This will benefit all Australians with a student loan and fix the issues of last year's spike in the CPI indexation rate of 7.1% and preventing growth in debt from outpacing wages in the future.
For an individual with an average HELP debt of $26,500, around $1,200 will be wiped from their outstanding HELP loan, pending the passage of legislation.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Clare

subdebateinfo.title: E-Cigarettes, Vaping Products and Tobacco Regulation

p.span: E-Cigarettes, Vaping Products and Tobacco Regulation
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 18 March 2024 regarding petition number EN5894, requesting removal of the purported ban on cigarettes (vaping products) or a reduction to the tobacco excise.

The Australian Government is taking clear action to reduce smoking and vaping rates through stronger legislation, enforcement, education, and support. This is because, despite Australia's success in reducing smoking rates over decades, tobacco continues to be the leading cause of preventable death and disability in Australia. There is evidence that non-smokers who vape are more likely to take up smoking, compared to those who do not vape. Normalisation of vaping has the potential to disrupt Australia's significant achievements in tobacco control.

The Therapeutic Goods and Other Legislation Amendment (Vaping Reforms) Bill 2024 (Bill) proposes to ban the importation, domestic manufacture, supply, commercial possession and advertisement of disposable single use and non-therapeutic vapes. The Bill builds on the Government's initial reforms to vaping products which commenced earlier in 2024, including a ban on the importation of disposable single use vapes from 1 January 2024.

The Government's vaping reforms are focussed on protecting young people and other Australians from the harms of vaping while ensuring those with a legitimate need to access therapeutic vapes can continue to do so.

The reforms will not prohibit the sale of all vaping products. Certain products will continue to be available where appropriate, through pharmacy settings. This accords with the latest advice on smoking cessation from the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners which states that e-cigarettes are not first-line treatment options for smoking cessation. Ensuring that e-cigarettes are only accessed with medical supervision provides an opportunity for users to receive personalised health advice and information on the risks associated with the use of vaping.

The reforms are focussed on strengthening the regulation of all e-cigarettes. These changes will make it easier to identify and disrupt the illicit supply of vapes and take enforcement action. To introduce and enforce these reforms, the Government is providing an additional $25 million to the Australian Border Force and $56.9 million to the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA).

To ensure appropriate access to therapeutic vapes is maintained, nurse practitioners can now prescribe vapes for smoking cessation and the management of nicotine dependence, together with medical practitioners. The process for these practitioners to follow when prescribing vapes has also been simplified. More information is available at www.tga.gov.au/resources/resource/guidance/ vapes-information-prescribers.

In relation to the taxation of tobacco products, higher cigarette prices are widely recognised as one of the most effective ways to reduce smoking prevalence when implemented as part of a comprehensive approach to tobacco control. Tobacco excise also helps pay for essential services such as the delivery of health services, treatment of tobacco related illness, and other areas of spending that benefit the whole Australian community.

Research in Australia and overseas has found that lower income groups such as young people and lower socio-economic populations tend to be responsive to price increases. The greatest health and economic l:!enefits from reductions in tobacco use are experienced by the most disadvantaged populations, whose tobacco use declines more with price increases.

The Government continues to provide support for people who vape and/or smoke to quit and remain tobacco and vape free. Support is available from health professionals such as GPs, pharmacists, nurses, and specialists. Confidential advice is also available through Quitline

(13 78 48).Smoking cessation products that have been approved by the TGA following a rigorous assessment of their safety, quality, and efficacy also continue to be available, and some products are subsidised under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
The Government has also committed to several activities to increase vaping and smoking cessation support. These initiatives will build on existing measures and resources and include:
